text:
Sawaddee ka it's the pajama party on hot 
Thai kitchen because that's right we are

making breakfast for the first time on hot 
Thai Kitchen history and we are making none

other than the most popular breakfast in 
Thailand Jok or rice porridge also known

as congee now Jok is so popular in Thailand 
that in fact McDonald's Thailand offers it

on their breakfast menu it's called mcpaul so 
you can try that out if you want it's got fried

chicken in it but we're not going to do that 
we're going to do the traditional old-school

one which is don't move stop or talk with chunks 
of seasoned ground pork very very good now dog

actually takes quite a while to make from 
start to finish and I'm sure for breakfast

you don't want to be you know getting up an 
hour early to make it so as we proceed I'll

talk about what kind of things you can do to get 
it ready in advance so that comes breakfast time

it'll be ready for you in ten minutes so the 
first thing we have to prep is the seasoned

ground pork which is the most important part 
of this dish so let's look at our ingredients

so we're working with ground pork already but 
we're going to grind it down even further in the

food processor because commercially ground pork is 
quite chunky and coarse but what we want here is

for the pork to be ground down to a really really 
fine paste so that the fat gets distributed and

the poor going to become super tender we're going 
to throw in our seasoning our soy sauce our fish

sauce a little bit of white pepper the more the 
better as much as you can handle it's very white

peppery dish and some sugar now this is a little 
bit more sugar than you might expect but the pork

is going to have a little bit of sweetness which 
is going to contrast really well with the salty

rice that's around it trust me it'll work really 
really good and we're also going to throw in an

ice cube which is really there to keep everything 
cold and the reason because when you grind things

in a food processor it heats up quite a bit and 
if it heats up too much especially if the pork

wasn't straight out of the fridge it the fat 
will start to separate out and then we'll lose

all that tenderizing effect they do the same thing 
in sausage making for a small amount like this is

a quick grind so it's not a big deal but if you're 
making more or if it's a hot day then it's a good

precaution to take so we're going to grind that 
up okay now it's um looks very very appetizing

I know I'm going to portion this directly into the 
soup pot but if you want to make it in advance you

want to portion it into little chunks right now 
lay them out in a flat plate and put it in the

freezer and then when you're when they're frozen 
consolidate them into a bag and then when you're

ready to use you can just throw them in to the 
pot but I'm just going to set this aside right

now and now we're going to go and make our rice so 
now we're going to make what I call the rice base

for the joke and we're basically just going to 
cook the rice so I've got here three quarters of

a cup of broken rice with chaff washed and broken 
rice coming up package like this just like regular

rice and it is exactly what it sounds like is rice 
it's broken into small pieces and it's good for

job because it cooks faster and it also gives 
a finer texture but you don't absolutely need

it if you're not going to make dough often just 
use but just use regular rice if you just have

to cook it a little longer and it might not be 
as fine of a texture but it works just as well

if you are going to make dough quite a bit it's 
actually cheaper to buy broken rice so it's a

factor to think about so I've got four cups of 
water here that I'm going to bring to a boil and

then I'm just going to go in with our rice now 
in the beginning you don't have to be stirring

as much just every once in a while is good as soon 
as it comes back to a full boil again then you can

really just let it go because the rice is just 
kind of dancing around it's not sitting at the

bottom and so it's not going to burn once the 
rice has thickened up however several minutes

from now you want to be here stirring religiously 
because it's so thick and the starches come out

and if you don't stir it it will burn and stick 
to the bottom and you don't want that okay yeh

now the rice is dancing the rice is dancing and 
we're gonna let it go and you don't want to walk

away at this point because at any moment now it's 
going to turn thick and as soon as it turns thick

that's the critical moment okay so at this point 
it's kind of in the middle stage its thickened up

but it's still too runny and also the grains are 
still too intact they're not mushy enough yet and

you'd use your judgment and what you're looking 
for is for the rice to look at a distance like

it's a paste like it's one mass but upon closer 
inspection you can still see the grains but the

grains are not intact anymore they're kind of semi 
solid so we're going to keep going and if you feel

like okay it's really thick now but the grains 
are not broken down as much as you'd like yet

you add a little more water give it something to 
work with and four to five cups of rice is what I

find to be the amount need it and the total amount 
of time should take you about 30 minutes if it's a

little longer don't worry it's fine so the rice 
is ready now as you can see it's very thick and

pasty and it looks from far away like it's a big 
mass of goodness but it's you look at it closer

you can still see the grains now I'm going to turn 
it off so I don't get bubble burns you can get it

more broken down if you wish just keep going and 
keep stirring or you can have it less broken down

if you wish just stop earlier than I did so it's 
completely up to you the texture of your rice is

kind of a personal thing you can make the rice 
up to this point in advance because from here

it's literally going to take you ten minutes if 
you've got the pork and everything else ready

it's going to take you ten minutes to put together 
and this will keep in the fridge for quite a long

time I've had it last me a week the only thing is 
you need to cool it down quickly because a thick

paste like this takes a long time to cool and if 
you let it sit at a warmish temperature too long

that's a foodborne illness hazard ready to happen 
so you want to chill it in a flat wide container

and then put it in the fridge as soon as it's 
cool enough to go in you don't want to leave it

out all day or anything like that but so now that 
we've got that ready there is one more thing we

need to do so the last thing we have to get ready 
before we put a joke together is the egg now it's

optional when you go to buy joke in Thailand you 
can tell them either dockside K which is joke with

egg or maokai or you don't want egg so either way 
I really like it I think it really asks a lot but

it's not just cracking an egg into the bowl we 
make what's called Kailua which is a very very

soft boiled egg and the way you do that is to get 
one egg put it in a bowl and then you're going to

get off the boil water which is happening right 
now and then you're going to slow oh by the way

the egg is at room temperature this method 
works at room temperature eggs and you're

going to slowly pour the water into the bowl 
now I'm doing this slowly because one I want

water to cool off a bit because if it's too hot 
the egg will cook a little bit too much and it

won't come out as easily you see what I mean when 
we go crack it second of all I want the eggs to

heat up gradually so it won't crack but if it 
does it's really not a big deal I've done it

in it crackling it's still fine on the inside and 
also it'll cook more evenly if you do it gradually

and now I'm going to stop it just when the egg 
is completely completely submerged and you're

going to let it sit for ten minutes which means 
I have to get my timer on and then at ten minutes

you're going to come out and shock it in some 
cold water take it out dunk it in cold water to

stop the cooking and that's it and then you just 
leave it like that and then when we're ready to

serve we will crack it open and we'll find out if 
I did this right so it's breakfast time and you've

got everything ready to go we're going to put it 
all together so I've got here three quarters of a

cup of pork stock now this is important your dog 
is only as good as your pork stock no good stock

milk with dough okay now lucky for you I have a 
tutorial on how to make good homemade pork stock

up already I'll put the link at the end and you 
can check it out if you are interested so we're

going to bring this to boil so it's boiling now 
now if you want a more concentrated stuff you

can start out with more and then reduce it and 
get even more flavorful - so next is our pork

remember our pork that we made earlier I'm just 
going to go in and portion it into the stove you

can sit there and make nice rounds if you want 
but it's breakfast it's supposed to look rustic

okay that's a little large that's okay you can 
make it as big or as small as you want really

that's all ah let's put in a little bit more bear 
yeah some people sit there and form them into nice

neat little balls I don't have time for that for 
breakfast okay so we're going to get that for kind

of cooked and then I'm going to season this with 
teaspoon of soy sauce and then a little bit of

salt you can go also I aasif you want but then 
that turns your talk a little bit an off-white

brownish color but if you don't mind that and 
you want soy sauce that's okay so I just went

in with a quarter teaspoon of salt and then the 
pork is sort of half way down I'm going to flip

that over well I make these big and then I'm 
going to go in with my rice base this is about

one cup of my rice base that we just made now the 
ratio is about 1/3 part stock to four parts rice

or three parts no two parts talk to three parts 
rice depending on how thick you like your job

and also depending on how thick your rice is to 
begin with if you cook this from cold we keep the

rice in the fridge and it's cold it'll come out a 
lot thicker I just finished the rice base so it's

a little bit thinner so you'll have to this is 
where you'll have to gauge how much stock needs

to be added and then you're going to just break 
up the rice lumps stir it up whoo that looks good

already just making sure that there's no bits of 
chunks anything so the amount of rice that I made

earlier it's probably good about three four people 
I think okay we're going to turn this off and then

we're going to go finish it off over there this 
is the exciting time perfect this is what you're

looking for this is Kylie walk so basically the 
white has coagulated enough so that it's turned

white but it's still runny and silky kind of like 
really loose tofu and then the heat of the dough

will cook it a little bit further the yolk should 
be completely runny if you have overcooked your

egg whites lightly it will be stuck to this shell 
and it won't come out in which case you just have

to run inside with a spoon there's not a whole 
lot here which is good but sometimes if your

water was too hot or you left it too long you 
have a thick ring of egg whites in the yolk I

mean in the shell okay perfect yeah in goes the 
dog mmm and I'm trying not to completely cover

the egg so it looks nice but if you want the egg 
to cook further you can completely smother it

with the rice and then the heat will do the rest 
okay and then we're going to do garnish with some

white pepper and then some green onions I think 
I've got some cilantro mixed in here as well and

must have is chopped finely chopped ginger mmm 
smells good already so this is classic garnish

okay now you may be wondering oh why didn't I 
just finish the whole thing and keep it in the

fridge and put in the microwave in the morning and 
yes you can do that but if you finish it and you

add all the pork and everything it won't last you 
as long it'll last you three four days but if you

keep just the rice base it'll last you longer 
because there's no meat or anything in it now

as you're halfway through eating the doke is going 
to start to thin out and that's completely normal

always happens what's going on is as you put the 
spoon in your mouth and then in the joke and in

your mouth and zuzo the saliva enzymes are going 
in and breaking down the starch in the porridge

so it's an irreversible process so you can't keep 
what's left in the bowl for later unless you don't

mind eating you know runny doke so take only as 
much as you can finish just the word of warning

all right let's taste it here's the funnest part 
is breaking the yolk yes mmm and then you mix it

all up make sure I get some pork some eggs some 
ginger making a perfect bite so comforting the

ginger is a little bit spicy the white pepper 
has that hot kick but it's still overall really

comforting food now when you go to Thailand they 
often have on the table little bottles of Maggi

seasoning sauce and people just use that to season 
it and it works really really well so most of the

time the joke will come quite mildly seasoned 
so you can add to your own delight and that is

it that's our dough and if you want the recipe 
you can go to ha hi kitten calm if you enjoy the

show please click to subscribe and I will see you 
next time for your next delicious Thai breakfast
